author: By Sam Roberts
title: William H. Pauley III, Judge in Trump Hush Money Case, Dies at 68
description: He sentenced Michael D. Cohen to three years in prison for breaking campaign finance laws by helping to buy the silence of two women who said they had affairs with Donald J. Trump.
content: Judge William H. Pauley III, the Manhattan federal judge who sentenced Michael D. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s lawyer, to three years in prison for paying hush money in sex scandals that could have threatened Mr. Trump’s presidential candidacy in 2016, died on July 6 at his home in East Quogue, N.Y. He was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: What to Do This Weekend
description: Movies, musicals and crispy tofu.
content: Welcome. The movies are back. Broadway is back. Public displays of affection are back. Travel is back (and it smells like weed). “Ted Lasso,” co-working spaces and even the goat landscapers of Manhattan’s Riverside Park are back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Greenberg
title: A Garden at Ground Zero
description: Even with harsh winds and little sunlight 10 stories above Broadway, you can beat the elements if you are persistent — and clever enough.
content: My partner, Esther, likes to say that she bought our financial district apartment right after 9/11 with the idea that someone would come along and make the terrace work. When I moved in a few years later, I was ecstatic. “I’ll make a garden,” I thought at the time. “What could go wrong?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: At British Open, Collin Morikawa Soars While Louis Oosthuizen Grabs a Record
description: After setting the 36-hole tournament record on Friday, Oosthuizen led at 11 under par going into the weekend. Morikawa and Jordan Spieth weren’t far behind.
content: SANDWICH, England — The scoreboard carrier on Friday looked even younger than Collin Morikawa, but the pace of changing numbers was getting to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: New Documentary Seeks to Understand Anthony Bourdain and His Death
description: “Roadrunner” takes an intimate look at Mr. Bourdain’s career and his struggles, using archival footage and interviews from members of his inner circle.
content: In 2016, Anthony Bourdain sat back in a leather couch to talk to a therapist in Buenos Aires, Argentina. It was the first time he had gone to a session since his parents sent him to one after catching him with drugs as a teenager. He put on his reading glasses, and went through a list he called “all of my ailments and problems.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: In Slain Haitian Leader’s Hometown, Fear and a Vow: ‘We’ll Kill Them, Too’
description: At memorial events for President Jovenel Moïse in northern Haiti, residents blamed the elite for his death, and their plight.
content: TROU-DU-NORD, Haiti — Northern Haiti feels like a place apart, its wide green fields and colorful churches seemingly worlds away from the gang wars and peril in the capital, Port-au-Prince, where political players are now vying for power in the wake of President Jovenel Moïse’s assassination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Red Flags Were Raised, but an Olympic Dream Was Dashed
description: Maya Wasowicz, a top karate fighter, was knocked out of qualifying under suspicious circumstances. A U.S.O.P.C. report backed up her claims, but Wasowicz still won’t be in Tokyo.
content: Maya Wasowicz was all alone when the last flicker of her Olympic dream died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: For U.K. Bands, Touring Europe Is Now a Highway to Brexit Hell
description: It’s not just that musicians need visas. Band merchandise is now a complicated export, and most tour vans are only allowed to make three stops.
content: LONDON — When the British rock band Two Door Cinema Club began playing shows across Europe a decade ago, the group’s three members would jump in a van, throw their instruments in the back and drive from their then hometown, Belfast, Northern Ireland, to sweaty clubs in Amsterdam, Berlin, and Paris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine J. Mach and A.R. Siders
title: Is Your Town Threatened by Floods or Fires? Consider a ‘Managed Retreat.’
description: When endangered by climate change, communities should  move away more often and in more innovative ways.
content: After suffering back-to-back floods in 1993, the town of Valmeyer, Ill., did something unusual. Instead of risking yet another disaster, it used funds from the Federal Emergency Management Agency and the state of Illinois to move the entire town a few miles away to higher ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Rattlestick Theater Focuses on Social Change in New Season
description: The theater will produce three plays in an ambitious 2021-22 season, but it has also committed to a five-day workweek and reforms that prioritize artists.
content: When Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, the West Village testing ground for new playwrights, reopens Aug. 14, it will be the same 99-seat, proscenium-arch venue where Heidi Schreck (“What the Constitution Means to Me”) and Jesse Eisenberg (“The Spoils”) have premiered plays. But some things are changing behind the scenes. Despite a heavier load this season, which will feature three, not just two, main-stage shows (to honor commitments to productions planned before the pandemic), rehearsals will take place exclusively during the five-day workweek, and no rehearsal or tech call will last longer than eight hours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Republicans Now Have Two Ways to Threaten Elections
description: A ‘house divided’ cannot support our democracy.
content: The story of voting rights in the United States looks less like a graph of exponential growth and more like a sine wave; there are highs and lows, peaks and plateaus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Health tips for coping with extreme heat.
description: How to stay safe if you’re going outside in triple-digit temperatures.
content: Dr. Maria Raven, chief of emergency medicine at the University of California, San Francisco, offers some tips for staying safe if you are going to go outside in the heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Marino
title: Stiller and Meara’s Upper West Side Home on the Market
description: The husband-and-wife comedy team had lived at the Riverside Drive co-op for half a century and raised their children Amy and Ben Stiller there. The asking price is $5 million.
content: The longtime Upper West Side home of the comedy team Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, an expanded co-op where they raised their two children, wrote and collaborated on material and entertained a host of celebrities, is coming to market for the first time in more than half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: End of Denver Broncos Ownership Dispute Could Lead to Team’s Sale
description: On Monday, a Colorado judge dismissed a lawsuit that contested the succession plan laid out by the team’s owner, Pat Bowlen, before he died.
content: The feud over the ownership of the Denver Broncos moved a step closer to resolution — and a potential sale of the club — Monday when a judge in Arapahoe County, Colo., dismissed a lawsuit that contested the will of the former owner Pat Bowlen, who died in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: These Scientists Took the Illogical Route
description: Emily Bick and Nora Forbes were wary about maintaining a long-distance relationship, but they pushed logic aside and followed their hearts instead.
content: Emily Bick was in New York, visiting her parents over the winter holidays in 2014, when the online dating service OkCupid rated her match with Nora Forbes, who was in Minneapolis, at 97 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: My Most Memorable Interview With a Residential School Survivor
description: A poet and educator talks about life in the former residential school near Kamloops as his First Nation looks at next steps.
content: Perhaps the best aspect of my job is that it enables me to meet and speak with people whose lives are far removed from mine. That sometimes includes prominent politicians, business executives, athletes and artists. But often, my most memorable interviews have been with people who are neither famous, wealthy nor powerful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Dara Khosrowshahi, Dad of Silicon Valley
description: The Uber CEO dreams of “pushing a button and getting a piano delivered to your home in an hour and a half.” Uh … let’s start with dinner?
content: LANGLEY, Wash. — I was just cutting into a juicy piece of steak that the chief executive of Uber, Dara Khosrowshahi, had grilled and plopped onto my plate, when one of his 8-year-old twin boys asked me: “Who was your worst interview and who was your best?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Cannes: This Is the Only Thing Gaspar Noé Fears About Death
description: The provocative director returns to the film festival with “Vortex,” a meditation on old age. Some are calling it his “Amour,” though Noé begs to differ.
content: CANNES, France — Gaspar Noé is a Cannes Film Festival fixture, but this year, he’s arriving just under the wire: After the director shot his new film “Vortex” in April and May under a cloud of secrecy, he rushed to complete it in time for a festival premiere. On Friday night, the last regular day of the festival, the film finally debuted; Noé had finished it just days before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francine Russo
title: Older Singles Have Found a New Way to Partner Up: Living Apart
description: Fearing that a romantic attachment in later life will lead to full-time caregiving, many couples are choosing commitment without sharing a home.
content: About three years after she was widowed in 2016, the Chicago psychotherapist Linda Randall, then 78, felt her friendship with a widowed man turning romantic. She’d dated him in her 20s, after taking her mother’s advice to volunteer as a candy-striper so she could meet a doctor. In 2015, while her husband was alive, she’d reconnected with him as a friend. But now, considering romance with this man six years older gave her pause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: Two Cheers for Carbon Tariffs
description: Saving the planet is more important than free-trade mysticism.
content: This time it really is Infrastructure Week. Democrats have agreed on the broad outline of a big public investment program, to be passed through reconciliation on top of a much smaller bipartisan “hard” infrastructure program. As I noted in my column Friday, big spending has gotten its groove back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Americans Are Flocking to Mexico. Should They Be?
description: U.S. arrivals are up, but so are coronavirus cases, especially in hot tourism spots like Los Cabos and Cancún. Experts urge caution, but visitors keep coming.
content: Mexico’s reputation as an alluring travel destination both before and during the pandemic has met a sobering reality: Despite growing vaccine efforts, the coronavirus is surging, especially in tourist hot spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Where Democrats Agree
description: President Biden’s ambitious legislative agenda faces many hurdles. But Democrats appear notably unified for now.
content: President Biden and his fellow Democrats face many challenges in trying to pass two ambitious bills — one on infrastructure, the other on social and environmental programs — this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sejla Rizvic
title: Can a Yarn Store Be a Place of Healing?
description: Crafting surged during the pandemic. But experts believe there are benefits to up-close-and-personal crafting that an online quilting class just can’t replicate.
content: Unlike so many small businesses, Downtown Yarns, Leti Ruiz’s yarn store in New York’s East Village, managed to make it through the pandemic intact. A surge in interest in crafting — including knitting and crocheting, the store’s specialties — brought both returning and new customers in search of comfort and distr action. When people were stuck at home, patrons placed orders over the phone or through Instagram and a friend of the store made deliveries to all five boroughs. In the end, the store actually fared better financially in 2020, Ms. Ruiz said, than it had in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Fear Street’ Trilogy Review: Carnage and Close Calls
description: Gore and nostalgia characterize this scrappy horror trilogy, which follows an endearing cast of teenage rebels through three time periods.
content: Like fresh entrails sewn into an old skeleton, the “Fear Street” trilogy is a new creature. Released on Netflix on consecutive Fridays, the three movies that make up the event straddle the line between weekly television and cinematic franchise. This Grand Guignol was an ambitious experiment for the streamer, and it mostly succeeds: “Fear Street,” an engaging and scrappy mini-franchise, plays like “Scream” meets “Stranger Things” built on a supernatural premise sturdy enough to sustain interest and suspense over nearly six hours.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Ibram X. Kendi
description: kendi transcript
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Ibram X. Kendi. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: This Is England
description: England, the country, is represented and reflected by its national soccer team: diverse and modern, progressive and compassionate. But there is another, darker England, too.
content: By the end of the day, the scrawl of abuse had been buried beneath an avalanche of sticky notes and hand-drawn flags, homemade banners and paper hearts. Affection and appreciation had so convincingly drowned out malice and hate that they had colonized the wall. Now, only the top half of the mural was still visible: the face of Marcus Rashford, rising above it all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suzanne Nossel
title: Thirteen Ways of Looking at Censorship
description: In “You Can’t Say That,” Leonard S. Marcus interviews 13 authors whose books for kids have been banned or challenged.
content: YOU CAN’T SAY THAT!Writers for Young People Talk About Censorship, Free Expression, and the Stories They Have to TellCompiled and edited by Leonard S. Marcus
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Regulators Feel Torn About Cryptocurrencies
description: Officials at the Federal Reserve and elsewhere debate the merits, or lack thereof, of digital assets.
content: Even crypto enthusiasts have mixed feelings about their culture and markets. So it’s no wonder that lawmakers and regulators are torn over digital assets, as developments this week made clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 16 No-Bake Desserts for Blazing Summer Days
description: When it’s too hot to turn on the oven, these treats will satisfy your sweet tooth.
content: No celebratory meal is complete without dessert, but, on blisteringly hot days, the mere thought of turning on the oven can make you wilt. (If you’re lucky enough to have central air, or don’t mind the heat, here are some summer fruit pies for you. Bake on!) These 16 no-bake recipes are for those sweltering days. A handful of these dishes require a little stovetop or microwave work, but the majority need no heat source at all, so you can stay cool while whipping up something sweet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Bourdain Documentary’s Use of A.I. to Mimic Voice Draws Questions
description: The documentary “Roadrunner” by Morgan Neville uses 45 seconds of a voice that sounds like Bourdain, generated with artificial intelligence. Is it ethical?
content: The new documentary about Anthony Bourdain’s life, “Roadrunner,” is one hour and 58 minutes long — much of which is filled with footage of the star throughout the decades of his career as a celebrity chef, journalist and television personality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly Whiteside
title: To Become an Olympian, Nneka Ogwumike Needs a Win on Paper
description: Left off Team USA because of an injury and denied the chance to play for Nigeria, the W.N.B.A. star is hoping a last-minute appeal can revive her dream of competing for a gold medal.
content: Basketball fans can see plenty of Nneka Ogwumike on the big and small screen this summer. She’s a member of the villainous Goon Squad in the film “Space Jam: A New Legacy,” which premiered Friday. And she’s featured in the ESPN documentary “144,” which chronicles life inside the bubble last season for the W.N.B.A.’s 144 players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Frank Askin, Fierce Defender of Civil Liberties, Dies at 89
description: A late bloomer in law school, he founded a constitutional rights clinic to guard against government overreach and was a longtime general counsel at the A.C.L.U.
content: Frank Askin, who enrolled in law school when he was 31 and devoted the next 50 years to defending the civil liberties of Americans suspected of being disruptive radicals, died on July 1 at a hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Stream These Five Action Films Now
description: This month’s picks span the globe and range from a solemn meditation on grief to a fight against bloodthirsty sharks.
content: For action fans seeking out new movies on streaming, there are plenty of car chases, explosions and fist fights to sift through. We help by providing some streaming highlights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Ibram X. Kendi on What Conservatives — and Liberals — Get Wrong About Antiracism
description: A challenging discussion on the hard, and sometimes unanswerable, questions around racism and public policy.
content: “What if instead of a feelings advocacy we had an outcome advocacy that put equitable outcomes before our guilt and anguish?” wrote Ibram X. Kendi in his 2019 book “How to Be an Antiracist.” “What if we focused our human and fiscal resources on changing power and policy to actually make society, not just our feelings, better?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Hart Island Timeline
description: A history of the many ways the island has been used over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman and Emily Schmall
title: In Pakistan, Textbooks Featuring Malala Removed From Bookstores
description: Authorities began confiscating a social studies textbook featuring a photo of Malala Yousafzai, the education activist, after she questioned marriage norms.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Provincial police in Pakistan this week raided bookshops and seized copies of an elementary school social studies textbook that includes a picture of the education rights activist Malala Yousafzai, a polarizing figure in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Cecilia Kang
title: ‘They’re Killing People’: Biden Denounces Social Media for Virus Disinformation
description: The president’s blunt statement capped weeks of frustration in the White House over the spread of vaccine disinformation on Facebook and other platforms.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden unleashed his growing frustration with social media on Friday, saying that platforms like Facebook were “killing people” by allowing disinformation about the coronavirus vaccine to spread online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Wildfires Are Intensifying. Here’s Why, and What Can Be Done.
description: The danger from flames and smoke is growing as blazes spread more swiftly and unpredictably as a consequence of climate change. Here are answers to five important questions.
content: By nearly every metric, the wildfires in the Western United States are worsening. They are growing larger, spreading faster and reaching higher, scaling mountain elevations that previously were too wet and cool to have supported fires this fierce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Ford and Mellon Foundations Expand Initiative for Disabled Artists
description: The foundations are adding $5 million to the Disability Futures program, which will continue through 2025 with two more classes of 20 fellows each.
content: The Disability Futures initiative, a fellowship established by the Ford and Andrew W. Mellon Foundations last fall to support disabled artists, is expanding. The foundations announced on Friday that they will commit an additional $5 million to support the initiative through 2025, which will include support for two more cohorts of 20 fellows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Jack Ewing
title: ‘We have to make the state more climate-proof,’ one official says in response to Germany’s floods.
description: Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the European Commission, was among several other officials who made the connection. “It shows the urgency to act,” she said.
content: The devastation in Europe caused by the severe weather came just days after the European Union announced an ambitious blueprint to pivot away from fossil fuels over the next nine years as part of plans to make the 27-country bloc carbon-neutral by 2050. Environmental activists and politicians were quick to draw parallels between the flooding and the effects of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Sciolino
title: The Louvre’s Art Sleuth Is on the Hunt for Looted Paintings
description: Emmanuelle Polack is the face of the French museum’s efforts to return stolen works. But some discoveries have put her employer in an awkward situation.
content: PARIS — In a frenzied, four-day auction in the grand hall of the Savoy Hotel in Nice in June 1942, buyers bid on paintings, sculptures and drawings from “the cabinet of a Parisian art lover.” Among the 445 pieces for sale were works by Degas, Delacroix, Renoir and Rodin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Sweet Summer Corn!
description: Yewande Komolafe’s corn and shrimp beignets are a perfect start to a party — or a festive summer dinner.
content: Hello, fellow home cooks. I’m filling in for Emily again this week and thinking about — and loving — the casual weeknight dinners of high summer. In my home, we often eat with our hands and pack up meals to enjoy the sunset at the beach or in the park. My kids’ friends drop in, and we squeeze around the table, pulling up stools from the kitchen counter when we run out of chairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: Changing Their Minds About Marriage
description: When Kevin White and Devon Bedell met at work in 2019, he was lukewarm about getting married and she was going through a divorce.
content: Kevin White had already decided that marriage was not for him when he met Devon Bedell in 2019, and she was trying to extract herself legally from the marriage she was already in. Not that they told each other that then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: Averting disaster, a broken dike is fixed in the Netherlands.
description: The Dutch military stepped in and prevented major flooding of an area along the overflowing Meuse River. Upriver more evacuations were ordered.
content: A breach in the dike along the Juliana Canal in the southern Netherlands on Friday was closed by the Dutch military by dumping hundreds of sandbags into the growing hole. Hours before, thousands had been told to evacuate after the dike was breached along the canal, a 22-mile waterway that regulates the Meuse River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Week 6: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 23 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 3.
content: Welcome to Week Six of our 12th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: It’s Hard to Search for a Therapist of Color. These Websites Want to Change That.
description: A number of new organizations aim to digitally connect patients with mental health providers who value and understand different cultures.
content: Several years ago, while Charmain Jackman was going through a rough patch in her marriage, she started looking for a Black, female therapist. At the time, she said, she was desperate to find someone who would understand who she was, as a Black woman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Steven Lee Myers
title: Blast That Killed Chinese Workers in Pakistan Was a Terrorist Attack, Officials Say
description: Pakistani officials had previously suggested that an accident sent a company bus into a ravine. Investigators now believe a vehicle packed with explosives rammed the workers’ convoy.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The explosion that killed nine Chinese workers and four others near a hydroelectric project in Pakistan on Wednesday was a terrorist attack, not an accident as officials in Pakistan initially suggested, according to a statement by the Chinese government and a top Pakistan official close to the investigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandip Roy
title: It Took Me a Long Time to Come Out as a ‘Plushie’ Lover
description: As the second wave of coronavirus battered us in India, my partner and I found solace and pride in our stuffed animals.
content: In the middle of a pandemic, I often talk to a little Chewbacca. He is a stuffed toy with bright blue eyes and a hint of a stitched smile. He used to make Wookiee roars, an ability he sadly lost after an overzealous bath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Craig, Mitch Smith and Shawn Hubler
title: Haunted by Past Virus Surges, California Leans on Masks and Vaccines
description: A new indoor mask requirement in Los Angeles County comes as new virus cases have nearly tripled statewide. Immunization rates, however, should keep any spike below past peaks.
content: LOS ANGELES — Last month, flanked by the “Transformers” robot hero Optimus Prime and a bevy of Minions from the “Despicable Me” movie franchise, Gov. Gavin Newsom triumphantly stood before the Universal Studios Hollywood globe, lifting more than a year’s worth of pandemic health restrictions and announcing California’s “grand reopening.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: What Ever Happened to IBM’s Watson?
description: IBM’s artificial intelligence was supposed to transform industries and generate riches for the company. Neither has panned out. Now, IBM has settled on a humbler vision for Watson.
content: A decade ago, IBM’s public confidence was unmistakable. Its Watson supercomputer had just trounced Ken Jennings, the best human “Jeopardy!” player ever, showcasing the power of artificial intelligence. This was only the beginning of a technological revolution about to sweep through society, the company pledged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Can Vaccinated People Go to the Gym?
description: Experts offer guidance on indoor fitness classes and more.
content: This week on Twitter I received a version of a question I’ve been hearing a lot: Now that you’re vaccinated, would you go back to doing (insert activity here)?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupam B. Jena
title: The Covid ‘Birthday Effect’ Crossed Political Boundaries
description: The politicalization of the coronavirus outbreak is undeniable. But what people valued and the risks they were willing to take have been similar.
content: A defining feature of the American experience of the pandemic has been the high degree of political polarization. There’s also a narrative, supported by studies of varying methodology and rigor, that Republicans and Democrats disagree about the risks of Covid-19 and the need for mask mandates, lockdowns and vaccinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Shipstead
title: Megan Abbott’s Latest Crime Thriller Links Ballet and Sex
description: “The Turnout” explores the darker, erotic side of professional dance.
content: THE TURNOUTBy Megan Abbott
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Yankees Add Aaron Judge and Two Others to Covid-19 Injured List
description: The team is up to six positive tests among players in the last week. At least one of the six was not vaccinated.
content: The Yankees were allowed to return to baseball on Friday, but without two of their best players. Aaron Judge and Gio Urshela, along with the backup catcher Kyle Higashioka, were placed on the Covid-19 injured list after testing positive for the coronavirus. All are expected to miss at least 10 days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: A Romance Bloomed Behind the Cameras
description: Jordan Hart and Sean Bredbenner both work in the film industry. They first met on the set of HBO’s “Paterno.”
content: Having a long, dark, Burt Reynolds-style mustache can be a blessing or a curse, depending on the circumstances. For Sean Welch Bredbenner, it turned out to be both one day in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

title: S.A. Cosby on ‘Razorblade Tears’
description: Cosby discusses his new novel, and Dean Jobb talks about “The Case of the Murderous Dr. Cream.”
content: On this week’s podcast, S.A. Cosby says that a writer friend once told him: “I think you’re like the bard of broken men.” In Cosby’s new novel, “Razorblade Tears,” the fathers of two married gay men who have just been murdered team up to track down the killers. Cosby says that the fathers — Ike, who’s Black, and Buddy Lee, who’s white — are familiar to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: ‘It went so fast. You tried to do something and it was already too late.’
description: Schule, a tiny village in Germany, was hard-hit by the flooding.
content: One of the places in Germany hardest hit by the flooding was tiny Schuld, where the sheer speed with which the destruction arrived shocked many in the once-tidy village of half-timbered houses decorated with geranium-filled flower boxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: The flooding swept away homes and part of a castle in western Germany.
description: Three houses and part of a 19th-century castle collapsed in surging waters on Friday in the German town of Erftstadt-Blessem, southwest of Cologne, where the swollen Erft River inundated the city, setting off a landslide.
content: Three houses and part of a 19th-century castle collapsed in surging waters on Friday in the German town of Erftstadt-Blessem, southwest of Cologne, where the swollen Erft River inundated the city, setting off a landslide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Clairo Takes a Defiant Leap on ‘Sling’
description: The songwriter and producer’s second album is proudly retro and humbly indie, drawing on her emotional epiphanies and anxieties about the music industry.
content: “Sling,” the second album from the introverted but openhearted musician Clairo, was inspired by two relatively common pandemic-era life changes: In the past year, the 22-year-old songwriter and producer born Claire Cottrill relocated to upstate New York, and adopted a dog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: The Pandemic Hardships of N.Y.C.’s Gig Workers
description: People like the ones who bring food to your door have been more likely than regular employees to confront health and financial challenges.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Francis Restricts Use of Old Latin Mass, in a Blow to Conservatives
description: The pope placed new restrictions on where the old Latin Mass can be celebrated and who can celebrate it, and will require new permissions from local bishops.
content: Pope Francis took a significant step toward putting the Roman Catholic Church’s liturgy solidly on the side of modernization on Friday by cracking down on the use of the old Latin Mass, essentially reversing a decision by his conservative predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Monsoon rains flood the Grand Canyon, leaving one camper dead.
description: Monsoon season brought heavy rain to the Southwest this week. Arizona’s governor declared a state of emergency for a hard-hit part of the state.
content: A woman was found dead and five people were injured after a flash flood in the Grand Canyon this week, the National Park Service said on Friday, as monsoon rains left parts of Arizona awash in muddy, fast-moving and potentially dangerous water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: She’s One of China’s Biggest Stars. She’s Also Transgender.
description: Jin Xing, the first person in China to openly undergo transition surgery, is a household name. But she says she’s no standard-bearer for the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
content: Jin Xing, a 53-year-old television host often called China’s Oprah Winfrey, holds strong views about what it means to be a woman. She has hounded female guests to hurry up and get married, and she has pressed others to give birth. When it comes to men, she has recommended that women act helpless to get their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Malcolm D. Lee on ‘Space Jam: A New Legacy’ and Directing LeBron James
description: The filmmaker recalls the “organized chaos” that went into making the new film and the studio pickup games with Chris Paul and other pros.
content: The making of “Space Jam: A New Legacy” was a head-spinning exercise in the unfamiliar for the director Malcolm D. Lee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Keith Bradsher
title: Yellen Says China Trade Deal Has ‘Hurt American Consumers’
description: The Treasury secretary said an agreement made by the Trump administration, which remains under review, had failed to address fundamental problems between the two countries.
content: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen has cast doubt on the merits of the trade agreement between the United States and China, arguing that it has failed to address the most pressing disputes between the world’s two largest economies and warning that the tariffs that remain in place have harmed American consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: When a First Date Becomes a Family Reunion
description: Just hours after meeting Anne Muscarella for the first time, Matthew Hayes was introduced to her aunts, uncles and cousins. He made a good impression.
content: Matthew Hayes was immediately attracted to Anne Muscarella when they first matched on the dating app Bumble in February 2018. “She had a big smile in all of her photos,” he said. “I could feel her warmth. I had a feeling that she would be a fun and real person.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Hendren
title: The Simplest Tool for Improving Cities Is Also Free
description: The pandemic taught us that time might be our most valuable resource for building the environments we want.
content: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — For decades, a stretch of Memorial Drive here that runs along the Charles River has been closed to automobiles on Sundays for the warmer half of the year. In the absence of cars on a four-lane thoroughfare beside the water, all kinds of other street uses blossom: skateboards, bicycles, hoverboards, strollers, wheelchairs and walkers, people on feet and on wheels now moving slowly enough to witness the late spring goslings, the ever-present sea gulls or the rarer magic and grace of a heron feeding along the water’s edge. A towering line of stately, centenarian sycamores forms an unbroken canopy over several blocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: After Strict Protocols, an Unconventional Relationship
description: Hillary Liepa and Dwight Lin met in 2013 at a diplomatic event in Beijing. They got to know each other through lengthy emails.
content: Just as was likely true of the diplomatic event at which Hillary Liepa and Dwight Lin met, in November 2013 — a Beijing luncheon between then-Vice President Joe Biden and his Chinese counterpart — the real work of building the relationship was done in email.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Retail sales rose in June in latest sign of economic recovery.
description: Sales of cars and car parts tumbled 2 percent thanks to a chip shortage that hampered supplies, but spending on clothing and at bars and restaurants rose.
content: Retail sales rose in June, the Commerce Department reported on Friday, an unexpected jump as American consumers increased spending on dining out and clothes and gadgets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: Promising to Love, Honor and Remain Quirky
description: Dr. Lauren Grossman and Glenn Kramon, who began their relationship through emails, had an instant connection when they met in person six weeks later.
content: Six weeks after Dr. Lauren Grossman and Glenn Kramon were introduced by mutual friends via email in November 2015, they had not yet spoken to each other, though they were undeniably smitten with one another.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Momentous Crush Goes the Distance
description: Chloe Snow taped notes decorated with hearts that said “Jai’s chair” on a seat next to hers in ninth grade history class. Jai Lakhanpal sat elsewhere.
content: Chloe Renfro Snow had an all-out crush on Jai Roberto Lakhanpal in 2009. She would tape a note that said “Jai’s seat” with hearts and squiggles about once a week to an empty seat next to hers in their ninth grade honors European civilization history class at the Severn School in Severna Park, Md.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charanna Alexander
title: Love Letter: Finding Unconditional Love in a Plush World
description: And: Legally married at last.
content: Who can resist a stuffed animal? They’re warm, cuddly, soft objects designed for comfort. While plush toys have been known to soothe a crying baby or bring joy to a curious toddler, many adults have found relief in them, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alwa Cooper
title: After the Main Event, a Communal Meal
description: Michon Sanders talks about a recent work of hers and about how living in Oakland, Calif., has given her a sense of freedom.
content: In each installment of The Artists, T highlights a recent or little-seen work by a Black artist, along with a few words from that artist putting the work in context. This week, we’re looking at a painting by Michon Sanders, who will attend a workshop at the Anderson Ranch Arts Center near Aspen, Colo., this summer. Her first solo show will open at San Francisco’s Friends Indeed Gallery in January 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: The Last of the Ptolemys
description: Sophia Maymudes and Kyra Wilson, together again.
content: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Some of us get really excited about puzzles. It could be working through one that feels made just for you, or reaching a peak in your streak or (bingo!) seeing the byline of your newest fave constructor(s). This week I’m thrilled to be writing about a Sophia Maymudes/Kyra Wilson production. I’m also a bit cowed. Can I solve it? This is a team whose grids I first encountered at The Inkubator, the subscription service that publishes edgy work and is dedicated to groups underrepresented in the conventional crossworld.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Aunts Is Back, Turning City Blocks Into Dance Floors
description: This creative performance experiment presents a roving adventure through space with Aunts Goes Public!
content: It wasn’t just that the barricades were pink, it was the shade of pink: shockingly vibrant, unabashedly joyful. On a steamy evening in June, these barricades were placed at either end of a Long Island City block, not just to stop traffic but to mark territory. For the next few hours, this was an Aunts-only zone. And while it can be tricky to describe exactly what Aunts is — it’s not an institution with a home base — it’s easy to say what it creates: a space for dance to happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: For Better, for Worse, for Free Branding Work?
description: You shouldn’t have to hide your relationships at work. But your work also shouldn’t creep into your relationship.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hailey Fuchs
title: A Pause in Federal Executions, but Uncertainty About What’s Next
description: President Biden’s Justice Department has ordered a moratorium on carrying out federal death sentences after a surge in executions under the Trump administration.
content: The routine usually began around 5 p.m. Inmates could hear the door to death row open and the jangling of keys. A convict would be escorted away by the guards to hear the news from the warden: His execution date had been set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Petersen
title: In Nicolas Cage’s ‘Pig,’ How Much Is the Truffle Hog Worth Anyway?
description: In the high-stakes world of truffle hunting, the bond between human and animal may be priceless, but the economics are real.
content: In the new film “Pig,” Nicolas Cage plays a prominent Portland chef named Robin Feld who left the city’s high-end restaurant scene to live in the Oregon wilderness, where he forages for truffles with his beloved pig. The reclusive chef is forced to re-emerge in the city after 15 years away to search for the beloved pig, which was stolen from him late one night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘There should not have been so many deaths from this event’: A scientist points to a warning issued days earlier.
description: National and regional forecasters knew about the risk of flooding days before this week’s deluge made its way across Western Europe with a deadly impact. But despite that advanced knowledge, many people remained in areas that were among the worst affected.
content: National and regional forecasters knew about the risk of flooding days before this week’s deluge made its way across Western Europe with a deadly impact. But despite that advanced knowledge, many people remained in areas that were among the worst affected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Elder
title: A New Radical Maneuver for Skateboarders: Going to Physical Therapy
description: Professional skateboarders have been slow to embrace the otherwise ubiquitous practices of elite athletes. That’s finally changing.
content: For the past three and a half years, Zion Wright, an Olympic-bound skateboarder, has been very serious about his training.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Yablon
title: Could Banking Magic Save Cities From Climate Disaster?
description: One way to avoid this circular debate on debt, taxes and spending is to provide states and cities with cheap, reliable low-cost loans.
content: A flawed but historically robust emergency response to the Covid-19 pandemic by Congress and our nation’s central bank helped America avoid the second Great Depression that so many prominent economists feared. Still, few progressives are declaring mission accomplished: The Biden administration and Democratic legislators are mired in political trench warfare over how to pay for desperately needed infrastructure and a climate change package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain and John Schwartz
title: ‘It Is All Connected’: Extreme Weather in the Age of Climate Change
description: The storm that brought flooding and devastation to parts of Europe is the latest example of an extreme weather event. More are expected.
content: The images from Germany are startling and horrifying: houses, shops and streets in the picturesque cities and villages along the Ahr and other rivers violently washed away by fast-moving floodwaters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Why the New Monthly Child Tax Credit Is More Likely to Be Spent on Children
description: Money seems different when it shows up regularly, influencing not only how people use it, but also how they think about government aid.
content: Hundreds of dollars began arriving in parents’ bank accounts Thursday, as the first installment of the Biden administration’s monthly child tax credit. Compared with programs that require a lot of paperwork or happen only at tax time, it was hard to deny the power of government assistance in the form of a direct deposit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Illinois Bars Police From Lying to Minors During Questioning
description: Gov. J.B. Pritzker, who signed the bill on Thursday, said the initiative was among three others that would move the state “closer to a holistic criminal justice system.”
content: Illinois on Thursday became the first state to bar police officers from lying and using other deceptive tactics when interrogating juveniles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Vatican Sex Abuse Trial Ends With Call for Six-Year Sentence for Priest
description: Gabriele Martinelli was accused of repeatedly abusing a fellow boarder at a seminary for altar boys before he became a priest. The seminary’s rector has been accused of looking the other way.
content: VATICAN CITY — The first trial involving charges of sexual abuse inside the walls of Vatican City ended this week, with a prosecutor asking that one defendant, now a priest, be sentenced to six years in prison. A verdict in the case is expected in October.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: After 20 Years, ‘We Never Stopped Being Married’
description: Jillynn Garcia and Darla Sims Garcia finally made their union official after their first marriage, in 2004, was invalidated by the California Supreme Court.
content: As part of the celebration of their wedding ceremony on June 2, 2021, and as a symbol of the ups and downs of the 20-year relationship that preceded it, Jillynn Garcia and Darla Sims Garcia made two Manhattan cocktails.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Europe Flooding, Delta, Broadway: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

title: How to Weather the Heat
description: Friday: Why extreme heat should be treated like other natural disasters, and how you can stay safe.
content: Good morning.

description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: No In-Law Jokes for These Two
description: Alexis Joondeph-Breidbart and Ryan Linden met online and fell in love, first with each other, then with each other’s families.
content: Alexis Joondeph-Breidbart let Ryan Linden know before their first date that if he wanted to win her over, he should come armed with better-than-average conversational skills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Building Solar Farms May Not Build the Middle Class
description: Some of the wealthiest companies in the world are investing in the green economy. But they’re not investing in paying union wages.
content: To hear Democrats tell it, a green job is supposed to be a good job — and not just good for the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Reyes
title: ‘The Heart That Keeps Us Together’
description: Once separated by continents, Eddie Rosenbaum and Dr. Donelle Cummings have now settled down together in New York.
content: In 2011, Eddie Rosenbaum had just returned to his hometown Cleveland from a year in Rio de Janeiro, when he and Dr. Donelle Cummings, who was headed for Brazil soon himself, found each other on a dating website for men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Chinen
title: Jazz Musicians Unite With One Goal: Celebrating Frank Kimbrough
description: The underrecognized pianist died suddenly last December. On Friday, his peers and former students will release a tribute album featuring nearly 60 of his pieces.
content: A couple of months ago, as the long, lean era of pandemic stillness was just beginning to open to new possibilities, some of the finest jazz musicians in New York could be found shuffling in and out of a Lower East Side recording studio as if through a revolving door. At one point, several of them — including the saxophonist Donny McCaslin, the trumpeter Ron Horton and the pianist Craig Taborn — delved into a wistful composition titled “Regeneration,” giving it all the supple dynamism of a banner rippling in the breeze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maura Kelly
title: The Unknowability of Other People’s Pain
description: While my father was alive, it was impossible for me to imagine his agony.
content: In the emergency department, the nurse asked me to rate my pain on a scale of one to 10 — “10 being the worst you can imagine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Fox
title: How Richard Nixon Changed America’s Place in the World
description: Jeffrey E. Garten’s “Three Days at Camp David” returns readers to 1971 and Nixon’s momentous decision to take the United States off the gold standard.
content: THREE DAYS AT CAMP DAVID
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: The village of Müsch lost its power, running water and cellphone coverage. Then it lost its bridge.
description: The riverbanks were scenes of devastation, with crushed cars and thick tree stumps, while many of the cobbled streets were covered with mud and debris.
content: Müsch, a village of 220 people at the junction of the Ahr and Trierbach rivers, was clobbered by the flash floods that have inundated this part of Germany. Only one person has died, but Müsch on Friday evening was without electricity, running water or cellphone coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Disastrous flooding in Western Europe.
content: Flooding caused by violent storms yesterday in Western Europe left at least 69 dead, including two firefighters who died during rescue attempts, in Germany and Belgium. At least 1,300 people remained missing as of last night, according to the German authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Hart Island’s Last Stand
description: After years of study, the city has declared an emergency to bulldoze most of the buildings on the city’s potter’s field, without following the usual environmental review process.
content: For more than 150 years, Hart Island, half a mile east of City Island in the Bronx, has been a depository of the marginalized, an isolated outpost to which the city has variously shipped the poor and unclaimed dead, the imprisoned, the sick and the troubled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Poriss
title: A Queen of 19th-Century Opera Gets New Attention
description: Pauline Viardot, born 200 years ago this weekend, was a famous singer, as well as a composer whose music is being salvaged from obscurity.
content: Toward the end of her life, the opera diva Pauline Viardot took stock of her vast social network. She wrote a three-page, multicolumn list of everyone she had ever met, worked with or loved.
source.name: The New York Times

title: State-Sponsored Abuse in Canada
description: Recently, the nation has had to confront one of its darkest chapters. We speak to a survivor of the state-sponsored maltreatment of Indigenous children.
content: This episode contains accounts of physical and sexual abuse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Flooding in Europe, in Pictures
description: Sinkholes that swallowed up houses. Streets disemboweled, their utility lines exposed. Cars carried away and deposited upside down. Homes emptied out, their contents mixed with mud.
content: The heavy rain and flooding that began on Wednesday in Europe has continued, with 106 lives lost in Germany by Friday, and at least 20 in Belgium. Hundreds of people are still missing, and the grim expectation is that many of them have not survived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At the British Open, Tony Finau Shuts Out a Sense of Frustration
description: The American golfer wants to win. But after finishing in the top 10 at major tournaments 10 times, without a title, Finau has a healthy perspective on outcomes.
content: Tony Finau shot a four-under-par 66 on Friday at the British Open and found himself in familiar territory. He was once again a contender for a major golf championship and knew that people would be wondering if it would end with another near-miss result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles, Jon Caramanica, Isabelia Herrera and Giovanni Russonello
title: Pop Smoke’s Memory Lives On, and 14 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Xenia Rubinos, Swedish House Mafia, Soccer Mommy and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Burdick
title: Measuring the Cost of Racial Abuse in Soccer
description: Plus, fluorescent flying squirrels, aging golfers and more feats of athleticism in the Friday edition of the Science Times Newsletter.
content: Like many soccer fans around the world, Paolo Falco, a labor economist at the University of Copenhagen, was delighted by the outcome of the European Championship final last Sunday, which saw Italy defeat England in a climactic penalty shootout. And he was appalled in equal measure by the aftermath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: N.Y.C. Jail Officers Sue Over Working Conditions: ‘It Was Hell’
description: The lawsuit comes as the city’s new correction chief acknowledged “severe” problems and promised to make changes.
content: One correction officer waited 90 minutes to receive medical attention after his appendix burst, passing out three times because of the pain. Another spent hours “in a wet uniform and in pain” when denied the opportunity to pump breast milk. Others said they regularly worked 20-hour shifts without bathroom breaks or access to food and water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Crispy, Cheesy Arepas You Won’t Soon Forget
description: A snap to make, these tender, sweet corn arepas de choclo from the food stylist Mariana Velásquez make an excellent summer meal.
content: In Colombia, where the food stylist Mariana Velásquez grew up, every region has its own variety of arepas. Some have more than one. Bogotá, Ms. Velásquez notes in her new cookbook, “Colombiana,” has at least 72 variations all by itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Africa’s crisis.
content: Africa is now in the deadliest stage of its pandemic as the Delta variant sweeps across the continent. Hospitals are filling up, oxygen supplies and medical workers are being stretched thin. Recorded deaths jumped 40 percent last week alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Chairwoman of Congressional Black Caucus is arrested while protesting on Capitol Hill.
description: Representative Joyce Beatty said she was protesting “in defense of our constitutional right to vote” when she was detained by the U.S. Capitol Police.
content: The chairwoman of the Congressional Black Caucus, Representative Joyce Beatty, was arrested on Thursday on Capitol Hill along with eight activists who were demonstrating for voting rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Banville
title: The Murders That Touched Off Ireland’s Bloody Campaign for Self-Rule
description: “The Irish Assassins,” by Julie Kavanagh, recounts the birth of a violent Irish nationalist movement through a fresh history of the famous Phoenix Park killings in 1882.
content: THE IRISH ASSASSINS Conspiracy, Revenge, and the Phoenix Park Murders That Stunned Victorian EnglandBy Julie Kavanagh
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: William H. Regnery II, 80, Dies; Bankrolled the Rise of the Alt-Right
description: The reclusive heir to a Midwestern textile fortune, he sought, through funding and organizing, to upgrade and update white supremacy.
content: William H. Regnery II, a reclusive heir to a Midwestern textile fortune who bankrolled some of the leading organizations and figures behind the rise of the alt-right and championed efforts to win adherents to a modernized notion of white supremacy, died on July 2 at his home in Boca Grande, Fla. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A Fashion Show That Pretty Much Was a Work of Art
description: Why Valentino couture in Venice was worth waiting for.
content: The Venice Biennale has long been a magnet for the fashion flock, a place to trawl for art and ideas the way it once shopped for buttons and trim in the garment districts of the world; to perhaps engineer the Next Big Art/Fashion collaboration, a mutually beneficial back-scratching arrangement of marketing and commerce that has begun to seem as mechanical as the Ford assembly line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Madeleine Ngo
title: Plans for free pre-K and community college could provide a ‘ladder into the middle class.’
description: For at least a decade, many experts and advocates have called for expanding the public education system to level the playing field for students from “cradle to career.”
content: WASHINGTON — What was once considered a progressive dream for the nation’s education system could be headed toward reality as Democrats push forward to broker a deal on a new spending plan containing President Biden’s most ambitious domestic policy goals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: U.S. Moves to Return Antiquity Said to Be Stolen From Cambodia
description: Prosecutors say a sacred work known as “Skanda on a Peacock” was sold at one point by Douglas A.J. Latchford, a collector who was accused of trafficking stolen artifacts.
content: U.S. prosecutors in Manhattan are planning to return to Cambodia a 10th-century Khmer sandstone statue said to have been plundered more than 20 years ago from a temple there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Richard Sherman Pleads Not Guilty to Misdemeanors After Domestic Dispute
description: Sherman, a longtime N.F.L. cornerback, was accused of fleeing a single-car crash and trying to enter his in-laws’ house by force.
content: The free-agent N.F.L. cornerback Richard Sherman pleaded not guilty to five misdemeanors in a brief appearance in King County (Wash.) District Court on Friday. Sherman was arrested early Wednesday morning after, the police said, he drunkenly crashed his car in a construction zone and tried to break through the door to the home of his in-laws in Redmond, Wash., a suburb east of Seattle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: High waters and washed-out roads are hampering the rescue efforts.
description: Everywhere, rescue efforts during the flooding in Central Europe were hampered. Electricity and communications networks were down, roads and bridges were washed out, drinking water was scarce. The worst hit were thinly populated, rural areas.
content: Everywhere, rescue efforts during the flooding in Central Europe were hampered. Electricity and communications networks were down, roads and bridges were washed out, drinking water was scarce. The worst hit were thinly populated, rural areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Chingos
title: Possible Winners and Losers in a Student Loan Proposal
description: Who would be helped by a 5 percent income cap suggested by the Biden campaign? High earners could wind up reaping the biggest benefits.
content: The Biden administration is still debating when to end the pandemic pause on collecting payments on federal student loans, but it’s also looking ahead at broader changes to how Americans repay those loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: Killing Time
description: If your idea of a great summer read involves murder, bloodshed, revenge and trickery, you’re in luck.
content: I am convinced that Derek B. Miller’s HOW TO FIND YOUR WAY IN THE DARK (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 368 pp., $26) was expressly tailored to my tastes and that I am its ideal reader. I suspect others will feel the same way; it’s that kind of book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: How a Champion of Black Culture Spends Her Sundays
description: Novella Ford of the Schomburg Center in Harlem can’t handle Zoom church, so she throws herself a dance party instead.
content: That Novella Ford’s name is book-centric and she works in the literary field is pure coincidence. “I was named after a friend’s grandmother who was from the South,” said Ms. Ford, the associate director of public programs and exhibitions at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, a division of the New York Public Library. “But in Harlem, when I tell people my name, they think of Novella Nelson, an actress who was involved in Black theater through the ’60s and ’70s.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: Toymakers Create Their Dream Projects (but Ask for Money Upfront)
description: Hoping to form stronger bonds with their fans, companies like Hasbro and Mattel are making once-in-a-lifetime toys through crowdfunding and other online strategies.
content: Thomas Brandt has loved the Masters of the Universe franchise since he was a child. Drawn to the sword and sorcery, he has gathered a large collection of He-Man toys over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: ‘Rogue’ U.S. Agency Used Racial Profiling to Investigate Commerce Dept. Employees, Report Says
description: An obscure federal office operated for more than a decade as an “unaccountable police force” inside the Commerce Department, using extreme and unauthorized tactics.
content: WASHINGTON — Officials in a little-known security unit within the Commerce Department conducted unauthorized surveillance and investigations into the agency’s employees that targeted people of Chinese and Middle Eastern descent, Senate investigators said in a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon
title: Why Virtual Weddings Are No Longer Legal in New York
description: During the pandemic, virtual marriage ceremonies became a symbol of love persevering in a trying time.
content: As ravaging as the coronavirus pandemic was, there were a few bright spots: dogs got walked more; humans discovered cocktails to-go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dennis Murphy, Impresario of Alternative Leagues, Dies at 94
description: He founded the American Basketball Association, which revolutionized the game, and participated in other imaginative, sometimes zany sports ventures.
content: Dennis Murphy, the impresario of alternative athletic leagues, including the American Basketball Association, who also shook up tennis and ice hockey and launched imaginative, sometimes quixotic ventures in other sports, among them indoor roller hockey, died on Thursday at an assistant living facility in Placentia, Calif. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: What You Need to Know About Campus Health Insurance
description: For some students, their parents’ coverage may be the better choice. The Affordable Care Act is also an option. Here are the pros and cons of the various plans.
content: Should you buy campus health insurance for your student?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: How New York Waiters Got the Upper Hand
description: Chronically underpaid and undervalued, restaurant workers are now in high demand, and the power balance may be shifting for good.
content: If crankiness is your default restaurant setting — if the bread basket is always too late and the scaloppine is always too cold and the manager better get over here — then the past few months have probably made you insufferable. Labor shortages stemming from the pandemic have affected a broad range of industries and the restaurant business acutely so. The problem is self-perpetuating. Obnoxious people throwing tantrums over lobster rolls that fail to arrive quickly only threaten to further diminish the supply of people who are willing to wait on them — ensuring a future of delayed lobster rolls.
source.name: The New York Times
